text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Wednesday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- One of the two men, suspected to be Chechens, who robbed an EU PHARE official on Sunday had a temporary pass to parliament issued by the head of parliamentary security.
- Deputy defence minister Jonas Kronkaitis said the Lithuanian army would buy U.S. made M16 and M14 rifles but declined to say how many.
- The leader of the pro-Soviet Jedinstvo group Valerij Ivanov was given one year in prison on Tuesday for slandering the victims of the 1991 Soviet military crackdown.
- The interbank loan market came to a halt in June, with no loans made.
- Vilniaus Bank is considering buying a stake in Ukio Bankas although no official moves have been made.
- U.S. credit rating agency Moody's intends to upgrade Lithuania at the end of August or the beginning of September. A one notch upgrading from Ba2 is expected.
- Danish Odense-Lindo bought a 16.27 percent stake in Baltijos Shipyard on the Vilnius bourse Monday. The Danes now run around 72 percent of the firm.
- The deputy head of the parliament foreign committee said Lithuania was devoting too much effort to join NATO and paying less attention to EU membership.
- MP Vilija Aleknaite-Abramikiene said Hillary Clinton told her during the womens conference in Austria that she would like to visit Lithuania.
- Carsberg and BBH submitted their offers to Utena Beverages and a decision is expected at a shareholder meeting on July 21.
- Unaudited figures for the first half of 1997 show that eight out of 11 banks were profitable.
- Hansa Investments, which owns 15.5 percent of Alytaus Textile, has stopped buying into the firm but declines to give a reason for its actions.
